front.question: Which of the following is not a component of the Apgar score?

cards.back: Body size

choices: is born before 38 weeks’ gestation or weighs less than 6 pounds.
weighs less than 5 pounds or is born before 36 weeks’ gestation.
is born before 40 weeks’ gestation or weighs less than 7 pounds.
weighs less than 5.5 pounds or is born before 37 weeks’ gestation.
front.question: An infant is premature if it:

cards.back: weighs less than 5 pounds or is born before 36 weeks’ gestation.

choices: assist in fetal development.
insulate and protect the fetus.
remove viruses from the fetus.
transfer oxygen to the fetus.
front.question: The amniotic fluid serves to:
front.source: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Female Reproductive System

cards.back: insulate and protect the fetus.

choices: high levels of protein in the patient’s urine.
seizures that result from severe hypertension.
a blood pressure greater than 140/90 mm Hg.
hypertension in the 20th week of pregnancy.
front.question: Eclampsia is most accurately defined as:

cards.back: seizures that result from severe hypertension.

choices: pubic bone.
xiphoid process.
belly button.
superior diaphragm.
front.question: By the 20th week of pregnancy, the uterus is typically at or above the level of the mother’s:

cards.back: belly button.

choices: has had only one live birth.
has never been pregnant.
is pregnant for the first time.
has had more than one live baby.
front.question: The term primigravida refers to a woman who:

cards.back: is pregnant for the first time.

choices: pregnancy causes an increased number of red blood cells, which predisposes the mother to anemia.
the blood naturally thins during pregnancy, which predisposes the mother to severe bleeding.
iron makes the blood clot faster, which protects the mother from excessive bleeding during delivery.
white blood cells decrease during pregnancy, which increases the mother’s risk of an infection.
front.question: Pregnant women are advised to take iron supplements, such as prenatal vitamins, because:

cards.back: pregnancy causes an increased number of red blood cells, which predisposes the mother to anemia.

retains heat better because of excess body hair.
is often covered with excess vernix material.
is one who is born before 38 weeks’ gestation.
front.question: In contrast to a full-term infant, a premature infant:

cards.back: has an even proportionately larger head.

choices: 3 to 5
5 to 10
front.question: A newborn infant will usually begin breathing spontaneously within _______ seconds following birth.

choices: pregnancy causes vasodilation and a lower blood pressure.
pregnant patients can dramatically increase their heart rate.
pregnant patients have an overall increase in blood volume.
blood is shunted to the uterus and fetus during major trauma.
front.question: A pregnant trauma patient might lose a significant amount of blood before showing signs of shock because:
front.source: See Special Considerations for Trauma and Pregnancy

cards.back: pregnant patients have an overall increase in blood volume.

choices: separates from the placenta shortly after birth.
contains two veins and one large umbilical artery.
carries oxygen to the baby via the umbilical vein.
carries blood away from the baby via the artery.
front.question: The umbilical cord:
front.source: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Female Reproductive System

cards.back: carries oxygen to the baby via the umbilical vein.

The uterus becomes very soft and movable.

Uterine contractions decrease in intensity.
front.question: Which of the following occurs during true labor?

cards.back: Uterine contractions become more regular.

choices: end of one to the start of the next.
end of one to the end of the next.
start of one to the start of the next.
start of one to the end of the next.
front.question: When determining the frequency of contractions, you should time the contractions from the:

cards.back: start of one to the start of the next.

front.question: Which of the following statements regarding a breech presentation is correct?

cards.back: A breech presentation occurs when the buttocks are the presenting part.

have gestational diabetes.
are pregnant for the first time.
are younger than 30 years of age.
front.question: A precipitous labor and delivery is most common in women who:

cards.back: have delivered a baby before.

premature delivery.
profound tachycardia.
respiratory depression.
front.question: Fetal complications associated with drug- or alcohol-addicted mothers include all of the following, except:

cards.back: profound tachycardia.

front.question: Which of the following is an indication of imminent birth?

cards.back: Crowning of the baby’s head

choices: ensure that it is thoroughly dried and warmed.
position it so that its head is higher than its body.
immediately clamp and cut the umbilical cord.
cool the infant to stimulate effective breathing.
front.question: After a baby is born, it is important to:

cards.back: ensure that it is thoroughly dried and warmed.

might not present with heavy vaginal bleeding.
is typically associated with severe abdominal pain.
is caused by hypertension or abdominal trauma.
front.question: In contrast to abruptio placenta, placenta previa:

cards.back: might present without significant abdominal pain.

choices: thorough drying with a towel.
suctioning of the upper airway.
some form of tactile stimulation.

front.question: Common interventions used to stimulate spontaneous respirations in the newborn include all of the following, except:

cards.back: positive-pressure ventilations.
